text: Hey everybody, today in this video we're going to be taking a look at manipulating audio inside of Ableton Live.

different ways of basically cutting up audio, warping it, chopping it and all of that sort of stuff.

we are just going to grab some that we'll use. So let's grab some sequences.

So when we're looking at an audio sample, there's a couple of different ways you can select it so that you can start manipulating and moving around.
So when you have your cursor on the top half of an audio clip, so this is the top half between here and here and then the bottom half between here and here.
When we're on the top half, we can click and we can select that clip and we can drag it and we can move it around.
If we were to click on the bottom half, it doesn't select to move the clip, but it selects so that we could make cuts in the clip or we could copy that particular part and paste it.
Or, you know, a bunch or we could go control L to loop just that particular part.
So let's have a look at all of the ways that we could copy a particular part of the audio.
So we have copy and paste commands like you would have in a word processor or image editing software or almost any other type of program on a computer.
So if I selected an area, remember on the bottom half, I can go control C and then I could come over here, click somewhere else on the timeline and go control V to paste it.
Or I could select it. I could right click. I could go copy.
And then I could right click and paste where I wanted to. But the quicker way of doing it is with the keyboard.
So then I've got a command so I could go control X, which deletes it from there.
But then if I go control V, it puts it over there. So the difference between copy and cut is in the name.
Copy will make a copy. Cut cuts it out from there and then it allows you to paste it somewhere else.
Another command that you can use to basically multiply things is a duplicate command.
So I could select that area and I could go control D. It copies it over and it duplicates the exact same audio.
All right. So if I play that now.
So it copied both of those over, so they are identical.
A quick command for zooming in on audio is I can click on the clip on the top half and then I can press Z and it expands it so that it's full screen.

I can come over to this big long one, press Z, it expands it so that it's full screen.

but it's going to keep that as a section of the arrangement view that it's going to basically be moving in on.
